monogr.title: A compendious chyrurgerie: gathered, & translated (especially) out of Wecker, at the request of certaine, but encreased and enlightened with certaine annotations, resolutions & supplyes, not impertinent to this treatise, nor vnprofitable to the reader: published for the benefite of all his countreymen, by Ihon Banester maister in chyrurgerie
monogr.author: Wecker, Johann Jacob

lg.head: The Booke to the Reader.
lg.l: I swellinges wast, I wounds do ioyne •
I vlcers do make sounde:
I doe the broken bones restore,
What further can be founde?

lg.head: To the Printer.
lg.l: Hast to the presse, feare not the sale,
good wine doth neede no signe:
The Surgeons craue this woorke to haue,
the gaine it will be thine.

lg.head: The Translatour to the Reader.
lg.l: Reade well, keepe fast, trye warely,
in no case me disdaine:
Commende of loue, amende with leaue,
this craue I for my paine.

lg.head: To the Translatour.
lg.l: If Weckers workes do praise deserue,
thy paines no man can blame,
Which both with new and needefull store,
enriched hast the same.
A worke well bredde, and better borne •
but • raynd vp passing well:
The phrase, the notes, supply also,
this same doth plainely tell.
If some wordes • o the daintie eares,
or simple sort seeme straunge,
Knowe this, that artes to termes are tied,
and may not lightly raunge.
If methods plat be not so plaine,
and perfit as some thinke,
Thine author did this way chalke out,
from him thou mayst not shrinke.
Thy tongue from tauntes by reasons rule,
so wisely hath beene stayde,

Momus eye cannot espie,
with fault thee to vpbraide.
Such is thy fru •• e that painefull Bee,
may honie sucke with ease.
But spi • efull spider cannot finde
her poyson to encrease.
Then armed with Achilles shielde,
Minerua standes thee by:
Though Hectors force doe thee assault,
there is no ieopardie.

lg.head: In praise of the Booke.
lg.l: As little Bee in broyling heate,
doth search the feildes abou • :
So litle Booke from Authours best,
best medicins sucketh out.
As precious pearle in li • le roome,
doth many vertues shroud:
So in this litle volume is,
much secret knowledg shewed.
As litle Sphere by due recourse,
doth heauens hygh vnfold:
So in this litle booke thou maist,
the wounde and cure behod.
A • loadstone doth the yron hard,
by secret force hold fast:
So litle volume in despite,
will enuye make agast.
As glittering Sunne with his bright hie •
doth other Starres deface:
So where this booke doth once appea •
i • others doth displace.
As Persian tree both flower and fruite,
doth bring foorth without staie:
So fruitfull is this booke to all,
in time, and place alway.
Then honie • ast, buy pre • ious pearle •
viewe spheere that turneth fast:
Feare loadston • force, walk by Sunne light,
〈◊〉 fruite that aye doth last.
